title-group.article-title: Mendelian insights: Irritable bowel syndrome as a predictor of upper urinary tract calculi

contrib-group.aff: aDepartment of Urology, General Hospital of Northern Theater Command, Shenyang, Liaoning, P. R. China
bDepartment of Graduate School, China Medical University, Shenyang, Liaoning, P. R. China.

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence: Renli Tian, Department of Urology, General Hospital of Northern Theater Command, Shenyang, Liaoning 110016, P. R. China (e-mail: tianrenli@aliyun.com).

The work cannot be used commercially without permission from the journal.

abstract.p: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) have a notably higher rate of consultations in urology clinics compared to other clinics. They often present with symptoms such as lumbar pain, dysuria, and urinary difficulty that are also associated with upper urinary tract calculi (UUTC). UUTC are the leading cause of nephrectomy in non-oncological cases, early screening for high-risk populations is deemed necessary. We investigated the relationship between IBS and UUTC using a two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) approach, with the primary analysis conducted using the inverse variance weighting method. To enhance the robustness of our findings, we conducted sensitivity analyses employing Cochran Q test, MR-Egger intercept, and MR-PRESSO. Additionally, we included type 2 diabetes in a multivariate Mendelian randomization analysis for further exploration. Our two-sample MR analysis, employing the inverse variance weighting method, suggested a positive association between IBS and UUTC, with an odds ratio of 1.47, a 95% confidence interval from 1.01 to 2.15, and a P-value of .442. Both weighted median and MR Egger analyses also indicated that IBS may be a risk factor for UUTC, although the results were not statistically significant. The Cochran Q test revealed no evidence of heterogeneity (P > .05). The MR-Egger intercept and MR-PRESSO analyses did not support the presence of pleiotropy (P > .05), and no outliers were detected by MR-PRESSO. Sensitivity analyses reinforce the reliability of our findings. Multivariate MR analysis further confirmed that IBS is a risk confirmed factor for UUTC, with significant results (P < .05). IBS is identified as one of the etiological factors for UUTC, enhancing our understanding of the gut-kidney axis. The specific mechanisms underlying this association warrant further investigation. Clinicians should consider the importance of monitoring for UUTC in patients with IBS.

institution-wrap.institution: Natural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is characterized by chronic abdominal pain and alterations in bowel movement patterns.[1] A meta-analysis incorporating data from 8 international studies estimated that the pooled prevalence of IBS was 11%, with substantial variation observed across different regions.[2] Associations between IBS and certain urinary system conditions have been established. Francis et al[3] compared the prevalence of IBS among patients in urology clinics and control clinics. They found that IBS was more prevalent in urology clinics (31.2%) than in control clinics (21.2%). The study further observed a higher incidence of IBS in individuals with complaints of flank pain, painful urination, and urinary frequency or urgency symptoms. These symptoms appear to be attributed to urinary tract infections (UTI) or upper urinary tract calculi (UUTC). UUTC is a common issue in primary healthcare settings. Simultaneously, UUTC and loss of follow-up are the major risk factors for renal insufficiency.[4] However, there is a scarcity of observational studies specifically examining the relationship between UUTC and IBS. Observational studies can be influenced by confounding variables, the issue of reversed causality, and multiple biases, making the causal relationships they establish unreliable. Mendelian randomization (MR) is based on the random assortment of alleles during the formation of gametes.[5,6] This results in the genetic variations being distributed in the population, which are usually independent of behavioral and environmental factors that confuse the epidemiological link between hypothetical risk factors and disease.[5,6] In certain instances, this can provide research designs that closely resemble those of randomized comparisons.[5,6]
Therefore, we aimed to investigate the potential causal link between IBS and UUTC risk through MR analysis.

sec.title: 2. Materials and methods
sec.p: Since the study involves a reanalysis of existing published data, this study does not require additional ethical approval.

sec.title: 2.1. Study design
sec.p: A two-sample MR study was conducted to explore the causal link between IBS and UUTC. The selection of SNPs as instrumental variables (IVs) adhered to 3 assumptions[7]: (1) a strong genetic correlation between the SNPs and IBS, (2) SNPs should not be associated with any confounding variables, and (3) no direct genetic association of the SNPs with UUTC. Additionally, we incorporated type 2 diabetes[8] into a multivariable analysis to ascertain whether IBS can lead to UUTC (Fig. 1).

caption.p: Three hypotheses for a two-sample Mendelian randomization study and multivariate analysis incorporating type 2 diabetes and IBS. IBS = irritable bowel syndrome; UUTC = upper urinary tract calculi.

sec.title: 2.2. Data source
sec.p: In this study, we established a relationship between IBS and the incidence of UUTC, with IBS serving as the exposure factor and UUTC as the outcome. The SNPs associated with IBS, identified by the query code ebi-a-GCST90016564, were derived from the GWAS study by Chris Eijsbouts and colleagues,[9] available for consultation at https://gwas.mrcieu.ac.uk/. This database contains data on 486,601 samples, with 9739,966 SNPs collected in the exposure dataset. Additionally, SNPs related to type 2 diabetes (query code: ebi-a-GCST006867) provided by Angli Xue and others[10] from their GWAS study, are also available on the same website. The GWAS data for UUTC, utilized as the outcome variable in our study, were obtained from the R10 release by the FinnGen consortium.[11]

sec.title: 2.3. Instrument variable selection
sec.p: The selection criteria for IVs to evaluate the impact of IBS on outcomes in our study included: (1) SNPs associated with IBS that reached the locus-wide significance threshold (P < 5.0 × 10‐8) were considered as potential IVs. (2) To mitigate the effects of linkage disequilibrium, we applied the clumping method to isolate independent SNPs, requiring an r² < 0.001 and a minimum distance of over 10,000 kb. (3) We excluded intermediate allele palindromic SNPs from our analysis. (4) The F-statistic was calculated as F = (R2 * (n ‐ k ‐ 1))/(k * (1 ‐ R2)), with R2 = 2 * (1 ‐ MAF) * MAF * (beta/SD)2. In this context, n denotes the sample size, k represents the number of SNPs, MAF indicates the minor allele frequency (similar to EAF in R2 calculation), beta signifies the allele effect size, and SD stands for the standard deviation.[12] An F-value >10 is often regarded as indicative of strong instrumental variables.

sec.title: 2.4. Statistical analysis
sec.p: In our two-sample MR analysis, we utilized inverse variance weighting (IVW),[13,14] MR-Egger,[15,16] and weighted median[17]methods. The IVW method was prioritized as our primary analytical strategy due to its robustness in identifying causal effects.

We intend to undertake sensitivity analyses to appraise the heterogeneity and pleiotropy, ensuring the reliability of our two-sample MR analysis results. We deployed Cochran Q test to evaluate the heterogeneity across SNPs, where a P-value below .05 indicates the presence of heterogeneity.[18,19] To detect pleiotropy, we used 2 approaches: the MR-Egger intercept[15] and the MR-PRESSO method,[20] considering a P-value under .05 as evidence of pleiotropy. We also applied MR-PRESSO to screen for outliers. In the absence of horizontal pleiotropy, the IVW analysis was deemed to be free from bias. To ensure the reliability of the observed effects of IBS on UUTC, we conducted a multivariable Mendelian Randomization (MVMR) analysis, adjusting for type 2 diabetes mellitus in the relationship between IBS and UUTC.[21,22]
For our MR analysis and subsequent sensitivity assessments, we used Rstudio (Version 4.3.2) along with the TwoSampleMR R package (Version 0.5.10).

sec.title: 3.1. IVs selection
sec.p: After completing the IV selection criteria outlined in Section 2.3, we identified 4 specific SNPs (rs10156602, rs12549729, rs7106434, rs9513519), which are detailed in Table S1, Supplemental Digital Content, http://links.lww.com/MD/N481.

sec.title: 3.2. Causal impact of IBS on UUTC
sec.p: The results from the IVW analysis indicate a positive association between IBS and UUTC, with an odds ratio of 1.47 and a 95% confidence interval ranging from 1.01 to 2.15, and a P-value of .0442. Both the weighted median and MR Egger methods also suggest an association between IBS and an increased likelihood of UUTC, although statistical significance was not reached, with P-values exceeding .05 (Fig. 2).

caption.p: The figure presents the outcomes of both the two-sample Mendelian Randomization analysis and the sensitivity analysis, with results considered significant at a P-value threshold of <.05. IBS = irritable bowel syndrome; IVW = inverse variance weighting.

sec.title: 3.3. Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: The sensitivity analysis indicates that for the Cochran Q test of IVW and MR-Egger methods, the Q values are 3.55 and 3.27, respectively, with P-values above .05. These results suggests no evidence of heterogeneity.

The MR-Egger intercept (P = .7221) provided no evidence for pleiotropy. Additionally, MR-PRESSO analysis revealed a P-value exceeding .05 in the global test, indicating no pleiotropic effects, and no outliers were identified (Fig. 2).

sec.title: 3.4. Multivariate MR analysis
sec.p: In the multivariate MR analysis that included IBS and type 2 diabetes, it was observed that IBS also exhibited a positive association with UUTC, with an odds ratio of 1.71, a confidence interval of (1.20, 2.43), and a P-value of .0029 (Fig. 3).

caption.p: The results of the multivariate Mendelian randomization analysis suggest that IBS is a risk factor for UUTC, with results deemed significant when the P-value is <.05.

sec.title: 4. Discussion
sec.p: In a two-sample MR analysis, we found a positive association between IBS and UUTC. This correlation persisted after adjustment for type 2 diabetes in MVMR. Our MVMR analysis showed that IBS was a risk factor for UUTC. The robustness of our findings is supported by the absence of horizontal pleiotropy, as evidenced by the nonsignificant results of the MR-PRESSO global test and the Egger regression intercept, and the lack of outliers in the IVS set detected by MR-PRESSO.

Maintaining a high serum vitamin D levels could be associated with a reduced risk of stone formation or recurrence.[23] However, IBS patients have been found to exhibit a deficit in circulating concentrations of vitamin D.[24] A possible mechanism underlying the increased risk of UUTC in IBS patients is calcium-phosphate metabolic disturbances secondary to their compromised vitamin D status. Individuals suffering from IBS demonstrate higher levels of inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin (IL)-1β.[25] The mouse model of IBS exhibits compromised intestinal barrier function, increased permeability, and elevated systemic inflammatory markers such as IL-6 and Lipopolysaccharide.[26] This may be caused by intestinal barrier dysfunction in patients with IBS.[27] Inflammation also plays a significant role in the pathophysiology of kidney stone formation.[28] Oncostatin M, belonging to the IL-6 family, could enhance the development of kidney crystal deposits by directly influencing renal tubular epithelial cells and renal fibroblasts to generate molecules that bind to crystals and inflammatory cytokines.[29] Patients with IBS often experience symptoms of UTI.[30] UTI are well-recognized as significant risk factors for the development of urinary tract stones. The relationship between IBS, UTI, and urinary tract stones is worth further exploration. Patients with IBS often have accompanying unhealthy lifestyle that are closely linked to urinary stones.[31,32] Consequently, further research is needed to understand the relationship and underlying mechanisms between these 3 factors.

In our research, MR analysis proves to be an essential technique, offering a robust framework for evaluating causality and address the constraints inherent in conventional observational studies. Utilizing genetic variants as IVs, we effectively reduced the risk of confounding influences and reversed causality, enhancing the validity of the causal connection between the IBS and UUTC. However, it is imperative to recognize certain limitations. Principally, our reliance on summary-level data from large-scale GWAS may lead to biases and inherit the flaws from the original studies. Moreover, our findings are based on European populations, which restricts their applicability to other ethnic groups. Future research should aim to include diverse ethnic cohorts to confirm our results. Lastly, due to the absence of specific databases, we were unable to perform subgroup analyses on the subtypes of IBS and the composition of stones. To advance our understanding of the gut-kidney axis, further exploration through mechanistic studies and functional experiments is necessary.

Given that UUTC are the leading nonneoplastic cause of nephrectomy,[4] identifying and implementing early preventive measures in potential at-risk groups is essential. This approach can significantly reduce patient suffering and is economically beneficial for healthcare systems. Our study results indicate that IBS is a risk factor for UUTC, highlighting the importance of vigilant monitoring for nephrolithiasis in IBS patients. This also enriches our understanding of the gut–kidney axis.[33]

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: Our MR analysis has identified IBS as a risk factor for UUTC, enhancing our understanding of the gut–kidney axis. The specific mechanisms underlying this association merit further investigation. It provides evidence for the necessity of monitoring urinary stones in patients with IBS.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: We would like to thank the MRC Integrative Epidemiology Unit (IEU) at the University of Bristol for creating the IEU open GWAS project and extracting the GWAS data. Our appreciation also goes to the participants and researchers involved in the FinnGen study.
